Array
Fundamentals

The most primitive and essential data structure ‚Äî a fixed-size, contiguous block of memory providing O(1) random access. Arrays are the backbone of nearly every algorithm and the foundation upon which all other structures are built.

What is an Array?
A collection of elements stored in contiguous memory locations, each identified by an index starting at zero.
üß†
Memory Model
Elements occupy consecutive memory addresses. Address = base + (index √ó element_size), enabling instant access.
‚ö°
When to Use
When you need O(1) random access by index, know the size upfront, or require cache-friendly iteration.
‚ö†Ô∏è
Trade-offs
Fixed size (static arrays), costly inserts/deletes in the middle ‚Äî every shift is O(n). Consider linked lists if frequent mutations are needed.
